repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Rural and Small Towns Water
            Supply and Sanitation Project (Praguas)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rural and Small Towns
            Water Supply and Sanitation Project (Praguas) in Ecuador
            were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: 1) The PRAGUAS project
            validates the viability of the demand-responsive approach to
            rural water supply to operate at scale at a national level
            and to deliver significant infrastructure outcomes over a
            five-year timeframe while involving rural beneficiaries in
            project selection, planning and operation; 2) The water
            supply and Sanitation (WSS) sector reform needs to move
            beyond line ministries and sector agencies to include the
            Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF), since sustainable
            sector reform requires the development of consistent
            financial incentives and coherent financial policies; 3) It
            is important to be realistic and acknowledge the fact that a
            community-driven project such as PRAGUAS requires more time
            to get acceptance from the community and start
            implementation; 4) In unstable country environments, a
            strong Project Management Unit (PMU) may be essential to
            project success; 5) The financial scheme of PRAGUAS was
            proven to be socially acceptable; 6) The on-site sanitation
            alternative of a basic sanitation unit comprising shower,
            sink and toilet (UBS) has proven to be an important success;
            7) The combination of technical assistance and clear,
            performance-based financial incentives for service
            delegation were effective in creating autonomous operators
            in a large number of municipalities; 8) Sustainability can
            be enhanced by pre-selecting municipalities that have: (i) a
            technical, social and financial team; (ii) municipal plans
            that include WSS and watershed protection plans; and (iii) a
            capable administrative/financial team; 9) Water Boards and
            communities should be assisted in the formulation of Social
            Plans that include community planning, tax payment,
            assessment of natural resources, and management of water
            sources; and 10) PRAGUAS' Operation Manual for
            financial and technical operations, administration, social
            control and auditing, should be disseminated more extensively.

repnme.cdata!:
Visible service improvements facilitate
            reforms in town water supply : PRAGUAS in Ecuador

abstracts.cdata!:
In 2001, the government of Ecuador, with
            financing from the World Bank, started assisting
            municipalities and local communities to carry out the Rural
            and Small Town Water Supply and Sanitation Project
            (PRAGUAS). By 2005, PRAGUAS had improved water supply and
            sanitation (WSS) services for over 250,000 people. The town
            component of the project supports municipalities which are
            willing to make their utilities more autonomous and to raise
            tariffs to obtain quick service improvements and choose
            their own management models. PRAGUAS has become the
            government's primary vehicle for addressing challenges
            in the water supply and sanitation sector. The objective of
            PRAGUAS is to increase the coverage and effective use of
            sustainable WSS services. It focuses on rural areas and
            small towns where two thirds of the country's poor reside.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Rural and Small Towns Water
            Supply and Sanitation Project (PRAGUAS)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural and Small Towns Water Supply
            and Sanitation Project, supports the first phase of the
            water and sanitation program in Ecuador, through investments
            in sustainable water, and sanitation services, focused on
            alleviating the poorest populations in rural communities,
            and small towns. Furthermore, improved policies will be
            developed, particularly through the implementation of sector
            reforms. The components call for: 1) sector reform, and
            institutional development, supporting a major restructuring
            of the Sub-Secretaria de Saneamiento Ambiental (SSA), to
            enable the agency formulate sector policies, and set general
            regulatory guidelines. Provision of technical assistance,
            and training to municipalities, and sector institutions,
            will enable SSA to define increased water, and sanitation
            coverage, and, set up a sector information system. Further
            training programs will be financed, which will allow
            non-governmental organizations, and private providers assume
            their roles in the new sector structure; 2) implementation
            of subprojects in rural areas, financing engineering, and
            infrastructure works in water and sanitation aspects, and,
            providing management training to the community, as well as
            health and hygiene education; and, 3) provision of
            non-refundable grants, to finance engineering studies, and
            civil works for water, and sanitation subprojects in
            municipal capitals.
